slidelink.displaytext: Outcomes of the Tuskegee Syphilis Study

search.slidetext: non-uk human subject protection training this course has audio. click “notes” to read along on each slide.

intended for: non-uk individuals engaged in human subject research. designed to: prepare investigators to meet their obligations in protecting the rights and welfare of research subjects. course intent adapted from materials provided by: the national institutes of health (nih) the office of extramural research protecting human research participants tutorial you must achieve at least an 80% on each lesson. jen hill - jen.hill@uky.edu

investigators tend to: overestimate the benefits of their research. underestimate the risks to individuals in their study. why it matters honesty trust respect this relationship should be based on: the relationship between investigators and human subjects is essential. 4 reasons 4 reasons ethical reasons legal & disciplinary reasons quality reasons guidance & tools nurse rivers draws blood from a participant in the tuskegee study in 1953. a prisoner in a compression chamber loses consciousness (and later dies) during an experiment to determine altitudes at which aircraft crews could survive without oxygen. dachau, germany, 1942. you face a dilemma.

tell a brief history of human subjects research and protections. identify contemporary dangers in human subjects research. argue for the continuing importance of human subjects protections. lesson 1 – history and context lesson, you will be able to:
human subject research getting it wrong mentally handicapped patients sleep in chairs at willowbrook state school, staten island, new york, january 1972.

nazi medical war crimes (1939-1945) “medical experiments” included: injecting people with gasoline and live viruses immersing people in ice water forcing people to ingest poisons. removing and transplanting bones, muscles, and nerves without anesthesia. 16 of the 23 physicians/administrators were found guilty and imprisoned. 7 were sentenced to death.

risks to the subjects should be minimized through proper preparations. experiments should only be conducted by scientifically qualified investigators. subjects should always be at liberty to withdraw from experiments. investigators must be ready to end the experiment at any stage if there is cause to believe that continuing the experiment is likely to result in injury, disability or death to the subject. voluntary consent of the human subject is essential. the experiment must yield generalizable knowledge that could not be obtained in any other way and is not random and unnecessary in nature. animal experimentation should precede human experimentation. all unnecessary physical and mental suffering and injury should be avoided. no experiment should be conducted if there is reason to believe that death or disabling injury will occur. the degree of risk to subjects should never exceed the humanitarian importance of the problem. the nuremberg code ethical code in response to nazi research the nuremberg code

investigated the effects of untreated syphilis in 400 black men from the tuskegee, alabama area. the researchers did not tell the subjects that they were in an experiment. tuskegee syphilis experiment (1932-1972) researchers withheld treatment for the disease from participants. the study finally ended in 1972, after a news story alerted the public to the ethical problems with the research. countless stakeholders generations of scientists 40 years 1932 – study starts 1946 – penicillin is widely available 1966 – peter buxtun protests study 1972 – newspaper article published 1972 – study stopped

national research act of 1974 basic hhs policy for protection of human research subjects national commission for the protection of human subjects of biomedical and behavioral research outcomes of the tuskegee syphilis study

common rule – 1991 revised common rule - 2018 other regulations federal policy for the protection of human subjects the office for human research protections (ohrp) the office for human research protections (ohrp) the office for human research protections (ohrp) department of homeland security central intelligence agency national science foundation department of health and human services environmental protection agency department of veterans affairs department of education department of defense department of labor department of justice department of housing and urban development agency for international development social security administration nasa department of commerce department of energy department of agriculture office of the director of national intelligence consumer product safety commission

on september 17, 1999, 18 year-old jesse gelsinger became the first subject in a gene transfer clinical trial to die from a reaction to a recombinant viral vector. jesse suffered from a deficiency of ornithine-transcarbamylase (otc), a necessary enzyme, and enrolled in a phase i dose-escalation trial at the university of pennsylvania. the clinical trial involved the injection of an adenoviral vector containing the gene. jesse died after receiving the injection. death of jesse gelsinger subsequent investigations found that the principal investigator was an inventor for the technology used in the trial and held equity in the start-up company to which the technology was licensed. this case brought significant attention to the issue of financial conflicts of interest in research. studies were carried out at the willowbrook state school for “mentally defective persons,” to gain an understanding of the transmission of infectious hepatitis. willowbrook study residents of the willowbrook state school, all of whom were children, were deliberately infected with hepatitis. they were made to ingest the stools of infected persons or receive injections of more purified virus preparations. jewish chronic disease hospital study studies were undertaken at the jewish chronic disease hospital in new york to develop information about the human immune systemʼs response to cancer. live cancer cells were injected into chronically ill and debilitated patients who were told they were receiving a skin test. the investigators were eventually prosecuted and found guilty of fraud, deceit, and unprofessional conduct. from 1944-1974 the atomic energy commission (aec) with the help of several other government agencies, including the department of defense and the national institutes of health, conducted over 4,000 classified radiation experiments and releases on millions of unknowing us citizens. these efforts were initiated in preparation for a possible nuclear attack during the cold war. human radiation experiments in order to assess how the human body metabolizes radioactive material, people were unknowingly exposed to the nuclear fallout from the testing of more than 200 atmospheric and underground nuclear weapons, as well as a hundred more secret releases of radiation into the environment. orphanages provided children food containing radioactive material, hospital patients received plutonium injections during routine stays, and deceased bodies previously exposed to radiation were exhumed without familial consent for examination. jesse gelsinger jesse gelsinger jesse gelsinger jesse gelsinger willowbrook study willowbrook study willowbrook study willowbrook study chronic disease study chronic disease study chronic disease study chronic disease study radiation tests radiation tests radiation tests radiation tests 1999 1955-1970 1952-1963 1944-1974 significant event timeline

contemporary events “none of the data used was associated with a specific person’s facebook account. there is no unnecessary collection of people’s data in connection with these research initiatives and all data is stored securely.”

henry beecher published an article in the new england journal of medicine describing 22 cases of human subjects research that involved ethical violations. beecher argued against increasing regulations and in favor of responsible investigators. his perspective has been cited as influencing federal policy to outline general requirements for informed consent and to delegate specific standards to local review processes. henry beecher 1966 – henry beecher’s publication the world medical association drafted the first international agreement recommending ethical standards for clinical research. like the nuremberg code, the helsinki declaration makes informed consent a central requirement for ethical research. the declaration does, however, allow for surrogate consent when the research subject is incompetent, physically or mentally incapable of giving consent, or a minor. helsinki 1964 – declaration of helsinki the first u.s. federal policy for the protection of human subjects was put into place for research conducted at the clinical center, nih. this policy provided a mechanism for prospective review of proposed research by individuals having no direct involvement or intellectual investment in the research. this system is the model for the current irb system. nih review 1953 – first u.s. federal policy for protection of human subjects the united nations adopted the universal declaration of human rights, which was inspired by atrocities committed during world war ii and states the conviction that human rights needed to be preserved at the international level. un human rights 1948 – united nations adopted universal declaration of human rights the american psychological association began to develop a code of ethical standards that included issues in human subjects research. apa 1947 – american psychological association click the logos next to the dates to learn more. there have been other important policies, regulations, and guidelines created to help the conducting of ethical human research. timeline of human subject protections 1966 1964 1953 1948 1947 click the “next” button when you’re ready to see more timeline events

the secretaryʼs advisory committee on human research protections (sachrp) was established to provide expert advice and recommendations to the secretary of health and human services and the assistant secretary for health on issues and topics pertaining to or associated with the protection of human research subjects. sachrp 2004 – sachrp the office for human research protections (ohrp) was elevated to the level of the u.s. department of health and human services, replacing the nih office for protection from research risks (oprr). the ohrp provides leadership for all 17 federal agencies that carry out research involving humans under the common rule regulations. the office has regulatory authority for the protection of human subjects in research and policies and procedures for institutional review boards. ohrp 2000 – the ohrp in response to a congressional mandate in the health insurance portability and accountability act of 1996 (hipaa), the u.s. department of health and human services (hhs) issued the regulations standards for privacy of individually identifiable health information. the privacy rule was enacted in response to public concerns over potential abuses of the privacy of health information. hipaa 1996 – hipaa privacy rule the council for the international organization of medical sciences (cioms) published guidelines designed to assist investigators from technologically advanced countries to conduct ethical research involving human subjects in resource-poor countries. these 15 guidelines addressed issues including informed consent, standards for external review, recruitment of subjects, and more. cioms 1982 – cioms guidelines fda established regulations for clinical research. the fda regulates research involving products regulated by the fda. this includes research and marketing permits for drugs, biological products, and medical devices for human use, etc. fda 1980 – publication of the fda regulations click the logos next to the dates to learn more. there have been other important policies, regulations, and guidelines created to help the conducting of ethical human research. timeline of human subject protections 2004 2000 1996 1982 1980

continue continue continue continue continue continue you did not select the correct response. incorrect continue continue continue continue continue continue that's right! you selected the correct response. correct drop zone which of the following human-subject research studies was the most influential event in leading to the hhs policy for protection of human research subjects? drag the correct picture to the drop zone. drag-and-drop interaction question #1 jesse gelsinger tuskegee syphilis study chronic disease study willowbrook study

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question #2 the nuremberg code the nuremberg code the nuremberg code the nuremberg code the nuremberg code the nuremberg code national research act of 1974 national research act of 1974 national research act of 1974 national research act of 1974 national research act of 1974 national research act of 1974 the common rule the common rule the common rule the common rule the common rule the common rule the catawumpus guidelines the catawumpus guidelines the catawumpus guidelines the catawumpus guidelines the catawumpus guidelines the catawumpus guidelines what was the name of the human-subject research guidelines that were created following nazi abuses in wwii?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question #3 the tuskegee syphilis study the tuskegee syphilis study the tuskegee syphilis study the tuskegee syphilis study the tuskegee syphilis study the tuskegee syphilis study the willowbrook study the willowbrook study the willowbrook study the willowbrook study the willowbrook study the willowbrook study the human radiation experiments the human radiation experiments the human radiation experiments the human radiation experiments the human radiation experiments the human radiation experiments the jewish chronic disease hospital study the jewish chronic disease hospital study the jewish chronic disease hospital study the jewish chronic disease hospital study the jewish chronic disease hospital study the jewish chronic disease hospital study which of the following human-subject studies was a major contributing factor in the passage of the civil rights of institutionalized persons act of 1980?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question #4 the belmont report the belmont report the belmont report the belmont report the belmont report the belmont report the beecher accords the beecher accords the beecher accords the beecher accords the beecher accords the beecher accords the helskini publication the helskini publication the helskini publication the helskini publication the helskini publication the helskini publication the declaration of human rights the declaration of human rights the declaration of human rights the declaration of human rights the declaration of human rights the declaration of human rights what is the name of the policy which is still considered the ethical foundation for human subject research in the u.s.?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue it’s the law. it’s the law. it’s the law. it’s the law. it’s the law. it’s the law. it helps you treat participants ethically. it helps you treat participants ethically. it helps you treat participants ethically. it helps you treat participants ethically. it helps you treat participants ethically. it helps you treat participants ethically. it improves your investigation’s results. it improves your investigation’s results. it improves your investigation’s results. it improves your investigation’s results. it improves your investigation’s results. it improves your investigation’s results. it gives you guidance and resources. it gives you guidance and resources. it gives you guidance and resources. it gives you guidance and resources. it gives you guidance and resources. it gives you guidance and resources. select all that apply. why is it important for investigators to be trained in human subject protection? question #5

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue honesty honesty honesty honesty honesty honesty trust trust trust trust trust trust respect respect respect respect respect respect awkwardness awkwardness awkwardness awkwardness awkwardness awkwardness select all that apply. what qualities should investigators establish in relationships with all research participants? question #6
conclusion summing up

describe a brief history of human subjects research and protections. identify contemporary dangers in human subjects research. argue for the continuing importance of human subjects protections. objective 4 text text text texttext text text text lesson, you should now be able to: course summary
exit course exit course exit course exit course exit course exit course

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Basic HHS Policy for Protection of Human Research Subjects

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Hello and welcome to the first of five lessons in the Non-UK Personnel’s Human Subject Protection training course! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In this first of five lessons, we will cover the history and context of ethical human subject research.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="This course has audio narration, which contains essential content. To read along, you can click the closed caption button in the lower-left corner of the player, marked “CC”. Or, if you’d like to mute the narration and read the content instead, you can click the audio button to mute, and click “notes” in the upper right-hand corner of the screen to view the narration in paragraph format." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="The study investigated the effects of untreated syphilis in 400 African American men from the Tuskegee, Alabama area. The researchers did not tell the subjects that they were in an experiment. Most subjects who attended the Tuskegee clinic thought they were getting treatment for "bad blood." Researchers withheld treatment for the disease from participants even when penicillin, an effective form of treatment, became widely available in the 1950s. The study ended in 1972, after a news story from the Associated Press alerted the public and Congress to the ethical problems with the research. The U.S. government settled a lawsuit brought by the participants and their families.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="This study did not happen in just one small corner of the country, or among just one small, tight-knit group of researchers. It involved many stakeholders and collaborators at local, state and national levels, who passed the work on through generations of scientists, all of whom continued the research and who didn’t ask questions about what needed to change – or stop – for over 40 years. And it had taken years of efforts to get the study halted or publicly noticed—Peter Buxtun, a Public Health Services employee, filed a protest in 1966 which was rejected. It wasn’t until he leaked information on the experiment to a journalist in 1972 that the study received enough attention and condemnation to finally be terminated." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Because the Belmont Report is a bit less prescriptive, efforts have been made to transcribe its philosophies into regulations and legislation. The most widely adopted of these attempts is the Federal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects (better known as the ‘common rule’). The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) issued these regulations, and many other Federal departments and agencies adopted them for their own use, including agencies like the Department of Homeland Security, the National Science Foundation and Department of Education. The Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP) provides a complete list of common rule agencies. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In 2018, the Department of Health and Human Services updated these regulations to modernize, streamline, and strengthen protections. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Congratulations, you’ve passed this lesson! Click the “next” button to record your score and exit.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Sorry, you didn’t pass the lesson. Click “Review Lesson” to look back over the lesson and your responses. Click “Retry Lesson” to make another attempt to pass." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
